threats.title: Developer commits secret to Git
threats.description: A developer may accidentally commit sensitive information such as API keys, passwords, or certificates to the repository, exposing it to unauthorized access.
threats.mitigation:
Use tools like git-secrets to scan for secrets and block commits containing sensitive information.
Implement strict code review processes to catch secrets before merging.
Use secret management solutions such as HashiCorp Vault or AWS Secrets Manager for secure storage.
Ensure all secrets are encrypted both at rest and in transit.

threats.title: Unauthenticated Administrator Access
threats.description: An attacker gains unauthorized administrator privileges through a misconfiguration or stolen credentials.
threats.mitigation:
Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all administrative accounts.
Use role-based access control (RBAC) to limit administrator privileges only to essential tasks.
Regularly audit administrator access logs to detect unusual behavior.
Enforce strong password policies and regularly rotate credentials.

threats.title: CI Pipeline Compromise via Malicious Code Injection
threats.description: A developer or an attacker injects malicious code into the CI pipeline, leading to the deployment of compromised applications or containers.
threats.mitigation:
Require code reviews and approvals before merging to the main branch.
Implement pipeline security checks such as static application security testing (SAST) and dynamic application security testing (DAST).
Use signed commits and enforce policies to only allow signed and verified commits.
Monitor build logs and pipeline activity for unusual behavior.

threats.title: Malicious Dependencies in Fetch Dependencies Process
threats.description: A compromised or malicious third-party dependency is fetched and used during the build process, leading to the introduction of vulnerabilities.
threats.mitigation:
Implement automated dependency scanning tools (e.g., Snyk, OWASP Dependency-Check) to identify vulnerabilities in third-party dependencies.
Use dependency pinning and lock files to ensure the same, trusted version of a dependency is used.
Only allow dependencies from trusted repositories and enforce an internal registry for approved packages.
Regularly update dependencies and apply security patches promptly.

threats.title: Compromised Container Image in "Build, Sign, and Publish Image" Process
threats.description: An attacker publishes a backdoored container image to the production registry, leading to the deployment of compromised services.
threats.mitigation:
Implement container image signing (e.g., Docker Content Trust) to verify the authenticity of the image before deployment.
Restrict access to production container registries to the CI/CD system only.
Regularly scan container images for known vulnerabilities using tools like Clair or Trivy.
Log and monitor all container registry activity, especially image pushes and pulls.

threats.title: Denial of Service (DoS) Attack on the CI Pipeline
threats.description: An attacker overwhelms the CI pipeline infrastructure with excessive build requests or resource consumption, leading to service disruption or degraded performance, delaying development and deployment processes.
threats.mitigation:
Implement rate limiting on build requests to prevent abuse.
Use auto-scaling infrastructure that can handle sudden increases in workload while protecting critical resources.
Monitor CI pipeline performance and set up alerts for unusual spikes in resource usage.
Ensure redundancy in the CI/CD infrastructure to mitigate service downtime during attacks.
Use Web Application Firewalls (WAF) and DDoS protection services to detect and block malicious traffic targeting the pipeline.
